Something got me wondering... In the '94 Crime Bill, threaded muzzles were listed as a feature of an 'Assault Weapon' because it could be used to attach suppressors. My question is why are suppressors listed as an accessory to this 'evil' feature since they are legal (by federal law and most states) to own? Yes they are restricted, but they are also easy to obtain for someone who meets the requirements. Also, when was the last time a civilian registered machine gun (yes, pre-'86 mgs are legal as well) or suppressor was used in a crime, if ever?

IT depends on you definition of "civilian". If police officers are civilians, it was 1996, when a chicago narcotics officer blew his top while questioning a suspect and put almost a whole clip inot the suspect. IF by "civilian" you exclude law enforcement officers, it has NEVER happened. Not one single time has a private citizen used a legally registered machine gun in the commission of a crime.
Has there ever been a case of assault that involved a bayonet attached to a rifle?

Has there ever been a case of assault that involved a bayonet attached to a rifle?

 
 
 
 Well I heard it was a big concern in la amoing gang circles as the drive by was becoming "cowardice". So there was a movment by both the bloods and crips to each lead charges by bayonet.
put it on pay-per view, call it a new extream sport.
